description: From Middle English slouthe, slewthe (“laziness”), from Old English slǣwþ (“sloth, indolence, laziness, inertness, torpor”), from Proto-West Germanic *slaiwiþu, from Proto-Germanic *slaiwiþō (“slowness, lateness”), equivalent to slow +‎ -th. Cognate with Scots sleuth (“sloth, slowness”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Laziness; slowness in the mindset; disinclination to action or labour.
examples: Sloth, like rust, consumes faster than labour wears.

entries.meaning: (countable) A herbivorous, arboreal South American mammal of the families Megalonychidae and Bradypodidae, noted for its slowness and inactivity.
(rare) A collective term for a group of bears.

verbs.description: sloth (third-person singular simple present sloths, present participle slothing, simple past and past participle slothed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive, transitive) To be idle; to idle (away time).
examples: […]  the most of professors are for imbezzeling, mispending and slothing away their time, their talents, their opportunities to do good in  […]
